b'I started Indigo Sands at the beginning of the worldwide pandemic. My anxiety and depression were at an all time high, and creating was the only thing that deafened the anxious thoughts and feelings. Playing with clay was the only thing that helped my mental health, and it still is.\xc2\xa0Which is why I use the hashtag #ClayToCope. I started with pottery and quickly found my way to the polymer side of clay, where I could both get my hands dirty, be creative, AND finish with a piece of art that you can wear.

Put me in a room with a desk, some clay and I\xe2\x80\x99m the happiest girl in the world. But turning that passion into a business didn\xe2\x80\x99t come without challenges. It took a lot of time, research, and support from my friends and family to figure out how things should run smoothly, and efficiently. That\xe2\x80\x99s one reason why I\xe2\x80\x99m so blessed to be a part of such a loving community of clay artists.\xc2\xa0

Getting to create polymer clay art every single day is an absolute dream come true, it truly means the world to me. I thank my supporters every day, because they allow me to keep creating. There is nothing like having someone adorn themselves with something that you\xe2\x80\x99ve made with your own two hands. The feeling is unreal.

My aim is to help any artist by uplifting and supporting them, so they can have a successful business. And for me consistency is key. I say this to myself almost every day, or to fellow artists as encouragement. There are times when you feel discouraged, run down, burned out and wanting to quit, but you CANNOT stop. You have to keep pushing. Because every day you work, is one day closer to the goals you\xe2\x80\x99ve set.\xe2\x80\xaa\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\xac

- Krymsyn, owner @indigo.sands

b"\xe2\x80\x9cWe launched Pipcorn when we were all in our 20s and so most of our time was spent working 7 days a week, 15 hours a day. We sacrificed most of our 20s and all of our money. It\xe2\x80\x99s a family business we started with $3,000, some hand-stamped bags, and heirloom kernels.
Using our special heirloom corn we wanted to recreate our favorite childhood snacks with sustainable and clean ingredients. We were on a mission to redefine what better for you meant, to go beyond the ingredients and include better for the whole family, our shared communities and the planet.

We are a trio who come from very different backgrounds from most people we sit in meetings with, so it means so much to us that we were able to make it this far. We are so proud to be able to also use our platform to lift up other people in our communities and do our part in creating a more equitable future.

Yeah, starting our business was hard but we have had the best memories, laughs, wins, and even setbacks and have learned more than we could have ever imagined. And it was 100% worth it. We wouldn't trade it for anything because our business means everything to us.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think I\xe2\x80\x99m a little different from other entrepreneurs because I\xe2\x80\x99ve always known that at some point I\xe2\x80\x99m going to walk away from @diasporaco. I started the business because I wanted to see globally sourced products have the same farm to table ethos and the same quality standards as local produce. I felt that I gained so much from knowing who grew my peaches and who grew my tomatoes and I felt like there was so much power in creating that connection in terms of who grew your spices on the other side of the world. The best part is that we are able to work with ten of the best farms from six different states across India right now and pay them 6X the price they were making before, which means they went from earning $4500 a year to now getting paid $26,000 a year. It\xe2\x80\x99s pretty amazing.

But I\xe2\x80\x99ve set it up so eventually, we can transfer ownership to our farm partners. I work in service of our farmers, my job is to market what they grow. Otherwise, the power always lies with the trader. I\xe2\x80\x99m the middleman right now between our farmers and our customers so the power lives with us. If we\xe2\x80\x99re actually all about building out a spice trade, the real solution is to give our farmers the power to be their own middlemen and truly be direct to consumer and we\xe2\x80\x99re trying to figure out how to do that. \xc2\xa0

It\xe2\x80\x99s also really meaningful to me because it allows me to retain a connection to my home, India. I moved eight years ago but my whole family is still in India. This allows me to live in both worlds and do work that matters to me. So in some ways, it\xe2\x80\x99s my whole world but in other ways I know that it won\xe2\x80\x99t be my whole world forever and that\xe2\x80\x99s okay because what\xe2\x80\x99s amazing is that I get to pass this on.\xe2\x80\x9c

\xe2\x80\x93 Sana Javeri Kadri, founder of Diaspora Co.\xc2\xa0

b'My wife and I started a business because we were tired of asking other entities for capital to invest in our own communities. We were both educators training youth in Memphis neighborhoods on how to use literature and the arts to build paths out of poverty. After helping to start a performing arts school in South Memphis that was closed due to lack of funding, we decided we were tired of waiting. The best way to do fund our non profit work in our neighborhood was to create a for-profit business around an industry that encapsulated all of our areas of passion. History, literature, the arts, and of course, coffee.\xc2\xa0

We work really hard to think and speak about coffee from Black and African perspectives, which can often lead to a sort of imposter syndrome when we look at other coffee companies in the industry. The Black story is kind of unheard of in our market. That\xe2\x80\x99s also become our biggest strength though. We\xe2\x80\x99re telling a story that has been ignored for a long time, and as such we\xe2\x80\x99re reaching customers who\xe2\x80\x99ve been ignored in the market as well.\xc2\xa0

Our brand and business represents liberation for our family and our community. It represents pride in our heritage and hope in our future. It represents ways out of poverty, opportunities for legal entrepreneurship, for those incarcerated by the illegal drug trade started by the war on drugs, and a chance to reconnect with a community we\xe2\x80\x99ve lost significant connections to because of slavery. Our coffee, Guji Mane, represents one of the most quintessential parts about Black diaspora culture, and that\xe2\x80\x99s our ability to take things that have colonial connotations and identify them as authentically black. The clearest representation of this is seen in hip hop. Through it we reclaim our past and reimagine our future. That\xe2\x80\x99s the power of sampling. And that\xe2\x80\x99s what we\xe2\x80\x99re doing with Cxffee. Learning from our African origins so that we can remix it to elevate our present experience.\xc2\xa0 We really feel like, in the most simple of ways, we are liberating our birthright.

- Bartholomew Jones, founder of @cxffeeblack

b'For MarLan owning his own business means freedom. He\xe2\x80\x99s created a business that provides him with a means to accumulate income 24/7. 

MarLan started @getlaced._ as a means of providing youth athletes and sneakerheads the opportunity to make their sneakers stand out. Having children involved in competitive youth sports and knowing many sneaker collectors, he knew that this was the lane that he wanted to be in.

But it was not without its challenges and sacrifices. MarLan struggled to accumulate capital. Any extra money from his 9-5 was re-allocated to the business. He would DJ on weekends, periodically, and put the extra income back into Get Laced. He had to grind to meet the needs of this business in the hours after work. He sacrificed family events, happy hours and countless nights working on the business...sometimes from 6pm to 1-2 am. But it was worth every moment because he was making his dreams come true. 

MarLan\xe2\x80\x99s biggest takeaway from all of this is to always be your own biggest fan: \xe2\x80\x9cPeople will not be excited about your business if you are not. And you can\xe2\x80\x99t be a silent fan either, you have to be loud, infectious and overly dedicated to promoting your business. Keep shining! Remember, the sun does not ask for permission..it just shines baby!\xe2\x80\x9d

b"Warning: This episode of My WTF Story deals with themes of trauma and domestic abuse.

Laura Hatt is a survivor of both physical and mental abuse. During her darkest moments of abuse, she took solace in the shower with the scents of beautiful soaps. Little did she know that this small reprieve would help her cope with her trauma and inspire a new business. With her history of domestic abuse behind her, Laura had been living safely and in a new partnership for quite some time. She was, however, still experiencing highly disturbing night terrors that made it difficult to rest. One day, while out shopping with her daughter she came across a soap-making kit and in the subsequent days made several bars of soap. Taking up this new hobby, she found herself sleeping peacefully for the first time in years. What she didn't realize was that this kit kickstarted both her healing and a new booming business @dolphinwoodhousesoap :dolphin:

b'\xe2\x80\x9cI worked at a health foods store for six years. I grew a lot during that time but I was at the top of where I could actually be - I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t become the general manager and I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t become the owner. My friends and family were always like, open your own health food store and although it was an intriguing thought, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how I could make it happen.\xc2\xa0

One day my boss calls me into his office and tells me about an opportunity in Vancouver. The health food store in Davie Village was becoming available. The owner, Susan St James, was ready to retire and she had owned it for thirty years. I had never been to that store but I flew out that weekend and checked it out.\xc2\xa0

By the end of my visit, I left the store and I gave it a little kiss and said, \xe2\x80\x98okay I\xe2\x80\x99m going to take care of you now\xe2\x80\x99. It was in that moment that I knew. I was so scared. I felt like I was going to puke but I knew this is what needed to happen. In three months, Nikki and I packed our bags and moved out here.\xc2\xa0

In that moment we went from being in a new relationship to being business partners. Not going to lie, it was hard. We had a lot of ups and downs but we\xe2\x80\x99ve gotten through it all and grown closer because of it.\xe2\x80\x9d

Deanna Henry, owner @gardenhealthvitamins

b"\xe2\x80\x9cI used to be a high flying consultant, constantly traveling to help clients open businesses in newly deregulating industries around the world. But after a devastating divorce, I uprooted my family from Wisconsin and moved to California.

When I got to the Central Valley, I was determined to create work and leadership opportunities for women like me. So in the Fall of 2009, I founded a non-profit collective in the most interesting deregulated market in California: the cannabis industry.\xc2\xa0

After three years of serving cannabidiol medicine to local terminal patients, I saw the need to share this safe, non-addictive and non-psychoactive formula with more people. And that\xe2\x80\x99s where the Sisters of the Valley was born.\xc2\xa0

My retirement funds went to starting this business and to keeping it afloat in tough times.\xc2\xa0Those sacrifices, any sacrifices have been a pleasure to make because I have an honorable, spiritual job and lovely, intelligent women surrounding me in a graceful dance every day as we strive to make our ancient mothers proud of the quiet, humble work we do. It\xe2\x80\x99s providing opportunities for careers, business ownership and property ownership for women and I believe the world won't be right again until [we afford women] this opportunity.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy parents owned a Chinese Canadian restaurant in Regina, Saskatchewan. My dad would cook in the back with my brothers and I served in the front with my mom and sister.\xc2\xa0

My parents were always at the restaurant, just trying to make ends meet. So I was like I never want to own a restaurant because I realized how hard it was. I have a lot of respect for people who run restaurants, but it just wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for me. So I went into real estate.\xc2\xa0

But one morning at 5am, I woke up and thought \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to start a healthy food line\xe2\x80\x9d and somehow gluten-free dumplings just came to me. And that\xe2\x80\x99s where House of Yee began. I went from real estate deals to researching gluten-free recipes. Real estate came quite easy to me but House of Yee is completely different. b'\xe2\x80\x9cI was forced into entrepreneurship. I always knew I was going to be an entrepreneur, I just didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how it was going to manifest. I think a lot of female-led companies start out finding a void that\xe2\x80\x99s not fulfilled and we create a product for ourselves, eventually finding others with the same challenge and turn that in to a business. So for me, I was just making hair products for myself and people started noticing my hair and complimenting it. 

Fast forward 18 months and I had a hair product line for myself, but I ended up getting laid off. I was the Global Digital Communications Director at Ford, so I had a big job with a whole lot of money. But I was also in the midst of leaving a very abusive marriage. It was abusive in every sense you can imagine - financial, physical, emotional. I left that marriage because I had a one year old son at the time and I knew that I was, essentially, raising someone else\xe2\x80\x99s husband. I refused to have him grow up seeing what was going on and have him thinking that's what love looked like or that it should be the norm. 

When I got divorced and laid off at the same time, I went from being the breadwinner of the family to being a single mom with $32 in my bank account. I thought, "Okay, I can either go find a trap house, hop on somebody\xe2\x80\x99s pole or try to sell this hair product I\xe2\x80\x99ve been working on." I went with option C. That was seven years ago and now we are in 1200 stores, sold on every continent and we've saved over 70,000 women more than 1.2 million minutes on their hair care. Not to mention I became the 1st Black woman in history to own a patent on a plant-based hair care product.

So that\xe2\x80\x99s how I got into entrepreneurship. It helped free me, because if I did not have this hobby and had not discovered this need, I would probably still be in a situation that was very harmful and it would have been my downfall.\xe2\x80\x9d

Gwen Jimmere, Founder @naturalicious_beauty

b"\xe2\x80\x9cThe Outrage started off as an online apparel company with a bent for social good. But we've really evolved into a 'hub for activism'- the apparel/fashion is one lever we pull on, and is one of our major revenue streams, but it is a small part of a larger mission. We're all about holding physical space for sustained civic engagement, connecting our community with the causes they care about and making it easy to meaningfully engage with a social movement.

We launched our VOTE boots, a collab with the shoe brand Naturalizer, to commemorate the centennial anniversary of the ratification of the 19th amendment. When we thought about this anniversary we knew a lot of brands would get it wrong and refer to it as women gaining the right to vote. In reality, the 19th amendment gave white women the right to vote and left many BIPOC women behind. While commemorating this historic milestone we'd like to center the women that were erased from history and the women who selflessly paved the way so that we could enjoy these rights. 

The sheer fact that women\xe2\x80\x99s equality has been given a day highlights the need to be holding space for this issue in every single political discussion.\xe2\x80\x9d

b"\xe2\x80\x9cTwo years ago it was raining heavily in Kerala, India and flood waters entered our premises. It was ankle deep at first, then knee deep, waist deep and well, the flood waters ultimately went up to 10 feet. We tried to save as much as we could - furniture, clothing, machinery but we lost a lot. We lost practically everything we had. 

We were rescued and and came back a week later to one of the most horrible sights I've seen in my life. My clothes were tattered and torn and hung on the fences. All the machinery was spoiled and everything was under water. We were preparing for our next collection, so we had a lot of work in progress. Everything was destroyed. It was horrible.

At that moment, I thought to myself, I want to quit. I can't do this. I just don't have the strength to build myself up back from scratch. When I got home word had got out about the floods. Once I could access my email, I saw that I had this huge outpouring of messages of people saying, \xe2\x80\x98Hang in there.\xe2\x80\x99 People were saying \xe2\x80\x98There's no way you can shut shop. There's no way you can give up. You've got get back on your feet and make these clothes.\xe2\x80\x99

You realize in that moment that in some way or the other, you have significantly impacted other people's lives. However small that may be. So I told myself, there are people out there who actually love the output of my creative idea. It doesn't matter, even if I'm just going to get back and be one tenth of what I was but I'm going to go out there and do it.\xe2\x80\x9d

Rasmi Poduval, Founder of @seamstress_india

b'I was diagnosed with muscular dystrophy when I was in my early 20s. I had this whole life before. I was able-bodied, able to walk up and down the stairs, lived on campus and then suddenly it all changed.\xc2\xa0

I was in such denial with even accepting the fact that I had muscular dystrophy. So I started writing my first blog on Tumblr and I started actually saying things out loud, like the symptoms and everything I was going through with the testing. And then it kind of took that moment like, "Wow, I have muscular dystrophy." After I wrote it I was like, "You know what? This felt good."

And then as I started posting on my social media platforms I got so much positive feedback from people. People were like, "Wow Keisha. I never knew you were even dealing with this.\xe2\x80\x9d It was at this time that I was like it\xe2\x80\x99s time to my put dreams to use. I'm a true believer that things happen for a reason. I loved wearing different graphic tees with inspirational quotes and things like that. So I was like, "You know what? Let me start a brand." How I came up with the name Girls Chronically Rock is that I knew I wanted something with the word chronic in it for chronic illnesses, but I didn't know exactly how I wanted to incorporate it altogether. So I honestly was laying in bed one night and I thought Girls Chronically Rock. It just came to my head. I loved the way it sounded. I loved the way it flowed. b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy grandmother taught me how to sew when I was seven years old. Little by little, every time I sat with her, she would teach me something new and eventually she taught me everything I knew. This lead me to pursue a career in fashion design and in my last year of college, I finally decided to go up to my professor and ask them if I could create a plus size collection. They told me it would be hard but they believed in me. With that collection I was able to present, for the first time, in New York City for Full Figure Fashion Week. 

It was a huge moment for me and it was the first time I was meeting the plus sized community. My collection was inspired by clothing that I wanted to wear, that I wanted to see other plus sized women wear. Soon after the fashion show, I received an email to apply for Project Runway. But it came two days after my grandmother had passed away. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t really know how to take the email. It was an amazing opportunity but I was at a crossroads. 

After losing my grandmother, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know if I wanted to continue designing because at that moment I felt like I lost everything - she was the one person who mattered the most to me and she was no longer here. But at the same time I felt like, why not go on this reality show and just put everything I have to offer on the line and just see what happens. 

When they announced the winner of Project Runway season 14 and it was MY name, it was like this huge weight off my shoulders. I finally did it, I finally did what I said I was going to do. I want to continue this business and see this plus sized community grow and finally have women feel confident in themselves because I know what it feels like to wake up every morning not happy. It\xe2\x80\x99s okay to be who you are, it\xe2\x80\x99s okay to be different and to really allow yourself to live and express yourself however it feels right to you.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 @ashleynelltipton'

b"Growing up in a small town on the outskirts of Philadelphia in the 80s, I was one of few kids of color in my circles. Although I had a fairly typical upbringing, racism and discrimination could not be avoided. Instead of responding with my fists, I'm eternally grateful that my parents taught me how to respond with kindness. This helped shape my path. Drawing upon my own experiences, I had an innate desire to understand how others responded to bigotry and inequities. Although I had my own missteps, I became an ally before I knew the word, a voice of reason looking to add more voices to the conversation whether it be speaking up against homophobic slurs on the ball field or denouncing sexist rhetoric in the classroom.

That sense of curiosity and social justice led me to careers in law and civil rights. Early on in my career I realized that the places I worked were highlighting my race to show that they were inclusive, as opposed to meaningfully including me. It upset me at first, but I had a mindset shift. I realized I could turn that lack of feeling like I belonged into an opportunity. Instead of being the one invited to share my singular experience, I could be the one building the strategy and setting the tone for the conversation. I could be one of the leaders I'd always learned from and looked up to.

Now, I lead the Employee Experience, Diversity and Belonging team where we're building a culture of belonging where every employee feels included, valued, and heard. We're building the foundations of a diversity and belonging strategy that will set Shopify up for the next 100 years, and we're collectively creating sustainable change at a company that has impacted not just the face of commerce, but the world \xe2\x80\x93 David King, Director of Employee Experience, Diversity and Belonging. #lifeatshopify"

b"\xe2\x80\x9cI had a very sideways path into the ballet world. Given my initial prognosis of being unable to finish school, she signed me up for ballet classes. Believe it or not, I was a professional ballet dancer for 18 years, prior to joining to Shopify.

Around the same time I started ballet, I had one of the first personal computers in my bedroom. When I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t dancing, I was teaching myself to program. Ballet is a very old art form and progresses at a much slower pace than technology, but combined, they provided a sense of balance. I had a strong passion for both, so I guess it\xe2\x80\x99s not surprising that I ended up working in tech after my ballet days were over.

As a software engineer, I use my mind a lot more than my body. I spend far more time keeping my skills up to date as a developer than I did my body as a dancer.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0But my markers for success haven\xe2\x80\x99t changed. b"We feature our independent business owners here all the time but it\xe2\x80\x99s usually us ~showing~ you their stories. So today we\xe2\x80\x99re handing our Insta over to Jacqueline and the @canadapooch team to take you behind the scenes of their puppy-filled world.

\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94
My entire life, I have had a passion for animals. I terrorized my parents as a child with non-stop begging for a dog. I went to business school and became an accountant, but always knew I wanted to centre my career around animals. Shortly after I qualified for my accounting degree, we adopted our first (of 3) pug, Bella. Bella had come from a puppy mill environment, and sadly she had never been outside of a cage for her five months of life, and was very unaccustomed to the outdoors. As we worked to help Bella acclimatize to the outdoors, we went to some local pet shops to find her a coat.\xc2\xa0 I found that the outerwear options lacked functionality and style, and I couldn't find any products I was excited about.  At the time, fashion-forward outerwear brands had become a massive trend for \xe2\x80\x9chumans,\xe2\x80\x9d but there were no options that offered similar style, function and quality for pets.

Like many entrepreneurs, my lightbulb moment happened when I identified a gap in the market from my own experience with Bella. I could see that there was room to create elevated products, and to build a brand that pet parents could turn to again and again to meet their pet outerwear needs. The brand has since evolved to lead the pet lifestyle category, with a wide range of products that include everything from rainwear to harnesses, and pet parent items such as dog walking fanny packs and gloves."
